Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part Twenty-three, Heaven of YÄma, Part Nine
Furthermore, in terms of karmic retribution, if a person is born in the heavens without ever giving in charity but only upholding the precepts to attain rebirth in the heavens,
he will only possess one kind of merit, and the merits of the five desires will be inferior to those of other heavens.
This is the karmic cause for humans being superior and the heavens being inferior.
At that time, Buddha VipaÅ›yin spoke a verse, saying:
Having given in charity among humans, one is then born in the good realms,
The heavens are unable to give in charity, because this is the realm of fruition.
Among humans, this is the realm of karma; the realm of fruition is the heavens.
All fruits are caused by karma; without a cause, there is no fruit.
Life does not abide moment by moment; it turns like this without returning.
When the fruits of karma are about to be exhausted, one should create merit and virtue.
All are the power of the mind, able to cause life to flow and turn,
Therefore, the wise do not do evil for the sake of life.
All are not afraid of future sufferings and afflictions,
Thus, people are bound by the snare of delusion.
The treasures of giving and keeping precepts exist in the deceitful mind,
If one is a god or a human, one will then reach the good path.
The arising, abiding, and ceasing of conditioned phenomena are all impermanent,
All conditioned pleasures are also like this, impermanent.
Although destroyed, one gives rise to craving, moment by moment, moving and not abiding,
Pleasure and life are all like this, therefore one should abandon them.
Thus, all conditioned phenomena are impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self.

In all worlds, immeasurable calamities and troubles are everywhere. There are five kinds of bonds that bind gods and humans, blinding the eyes of ignorance, and evil desires destroy the mind, only giving rise to love and joy.
All foolish ordinary beings mutually love and bind each other, like birds in a cage. All humans and gods in the midst of birth and death always wander.

For this reason, whether it is humans or gods, whether it is life or happiness, do not give rise to the notion of permanence. One should not give rise to the notion of permanence towards all dharmas in the world, and should not make immeasurable various distinctions.
Moreover, one is endowed with twelve kinds of giving. Such giving does not exist among the gods, but only among humans.
The gods only eat fruits. If the fruits are exhausted, they rot, decay, and lose their heavenly status.
What are the twelve kinds of giving that are complete?
First, the completeness of place;
Second, the completeness of time;
Third, the completeness of merit;
Fourth, being endowed with what is lovable, referring to beloved objects;
Fifth, being endowed with fields of merit;
Sixth, giving to the hungry and thirsty;
Seventh, giving with a faithful mind;
Eighth, giving without seeking, endowed with merit;ğŸ”½Ninth, giving with a joyful mind, such as giving one's wife and children;
Tenth, selecting and giving to those who are respected and superior;
Eleventh, giving to those in the world who are not despised;
Twelfth, giving without expecting reward.
These are the twelve kinds of giving.

Moreover, being endowed with the merit of upholding precepts, one can be reborn in the heavens, but once one's merits are exhausted, one will fall back. Therefore, the heavens should abandon heedless activities.
In this way, the twelve kinds of unstained giving lead to becoming a wheel-turning king, being wealthy and prosperous, or being reborn in the heavens or resembling the heavens.
There are also twelve kinds of mixed and stained giving.
What are the twelve kinds of stains?
First, in a gathering of many people or in the assembly, equally having the virtue of precepts, wisdom, and practice, one gives unequally.
This is defiled giving, obtaining little karmic retribution.
Second, whether male or female, due to the causes and conditions of desire, either the male gives to the female or the female gives to the male, this is the second defiled and evil giving.
Moreover, the third defiled giving is that out of fear, one gives away wealth to the king's family and teachers, referring to Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others, thinking like this:
If I suffer harm from the king, they will be able to save me.
This is not giving due to the causes and conditions of cultivation and reflection, called defiled giving.
Moreover, the fourth defiled giving is that of giving away wealth with a deluded mind, like the external path brÄhmaá¹‡as and others giving at ritual gatherings, etc.
This is the fourth defiled and evil giving.
Furthermore, the fifth type of defiled giving is when one sees others giving and does not know whether those people keep the precepts or not,
whether those people have wisdom or not,
whether they have tranquility or not,
whether they have meditation or not.
They only see others giving like this, and for the sake of others, they themselves do not think like this, and give away their belongings to them.
This is the fifth type of defiled evil giving.
Furthermore, the sixth type of defiled giving is when the beggar suffers and seeks to be given.
This is the sixth type of defiled evil giving.

Furthermore, the seventh type of defiled giving is when one knows that others have belongings, wants to deceive them, and skillfully wants to steal, gives away their belongings, and later wants to do evil and harm them in various ways.
In order to find an opportunity, they therefore give their belongings. This is the seventh type of defiled evil giving.

Furthermore, the eighth type of defiled giving is giving to others in order to break up their harmonious relationships, giving things to them, causing two people who are friends to become separated, and later seeking opportunities to harm them.
This is the eighth type of defiled evil giving.
Furthermore, the ninth type of defiled giving is giving things to others in order to form relationships, either giving a man to a woman or a woman to a man.
This is the ninth type of defiled evil giving.

Furthermore, the tenth type of defiled giving is giving things in order to make a profit, buying a lot of food and various other things such as millet, beans, fruits, and vegetables, and then selling them at a high price on the day of the fast, seeking profit. After obtaining the things, one uses them oneself and gives a small amount to others.
This is the tenth type of defiled evil giving.
Furthermore, the eleventh type of defiled giving is giving things in order to gain fame.
This is the eleventh type of defiled evil giving.
Furthermore, the twelfth defiled giving is when one gives to one's wife and children who are hungry and poor, but has no good thoughts in one's mind.
This is the twelfth defiled and evil giving.
All these kinds of giving are free from thought and non-thought. Because of non-thought, they are empty and without retribution. If thought increases, one can be free from defilement.
It is like a defiled garment that becomes clean when washed with lye.
In the same way, giving perfumed by thought is accomplished.
When Vipashyin Buddha was at that time, he spoke a verse, saying:
The twelve merits are complete, free from the twelve kinds of defilements,
Accomplishing pure giving, contrary to it is defiled.
Whether a god or a man, by giving one attains great power;
Free from giving, one falls into evil destinies, by giving one is born in good destinies.
The defilement of greedy mind and jealousy, only loving one's wife and children,
This person falls into the realm of hungry ghosts, only hoping for food and drink.
If one understands the bondage of greedy mind and cuts down the tree of arrogant mind,
And eliminates the mass of darkness, it is because this person practices giving.
Giving leads the way, and the giver follows behind.
Giving can show the way, and one goes to the other world by practicing it.
One who gives water to bathe in, and anoints with the fragrance of precepts,
With wisdom vast and without defilements, can cross over to the other shore of suffering.
A man has three lamps, which are lit for the benefit of others,
Namely, giving, precepts, and wisdom, which can eliminate faults.
Love is extremely deep and vast, and doubt is extremely agitated,
But by upholding precepts and cultivating wisdom, one can cross over this sea of suffering.
The mind is undisciplined and quick, attached to everything,
But the Dharma of giving and upholding precepts can bind this mind.
These three medicines can cure the afflictions' illnesses,
Generosity, morality, and wisdom always bring peace and happiness.
The mind has the fault of carelessness, discriminating crookedly and lightly;
Generosity, morality, and wisdom, these three can bind the mind.
The three kinds of raging fires burn all worlds,
The water of wisdom extinguishes the fires, and one attains the peace of nirvana.
The Tathagata Vipashyin, the World-Honored One, has written this sutra in that stupa.
This practice of generosity can only be done by humans, not by gods.
For this reason, humans are superior, and gods are inferior.
Since you know this kind of generosity, do not be careless in your minds regarding the objects of the senses. You should control your minds well.
Having controlled your minds well, you will prevent the great evil faults of the afflictions from arising in your minds.
If they do arise, the fire of wisdom can burn them away;
When burned by the fire of wisdom, one reaches the foremost place of non-retrogression, a place of non-birth, non-aging, non-death, and non-exhaustion.
One should abandon it as if it were an enemy or negligence.
Moreover, the heavenly beings have other matters that diminish their minds, causing shame and humiliation.
Namely, when it is time to eat, they are ashamed of what they see.
Due to the power of karma, there are inferior, middling, and superior [results], and the fruits are also like this, with inferior, middling, and superior [varieties].
Those heavens cannot give even the slightest thing to other heavens, and it is impossible to turn one's own karma and give it to others.
Namely, when eating among humans, one gives away what is left, or sometimes observes precepts, and thus obtains food.
The heavens see the superior color, superior fragrance, and superior taste of others' food, complete with everything. Having seen this, their minds are ashamed.
If they are playing in the gardens, forests, lotus ponds, and waters, experiencing all kinds of pleasures that accord with their karma and accomplishing joyful matters,
Seeing the faces of other gods enjoying pleasures, they feel ashamed in their hearts and their bodies become dejected.
There are five kinds of shame in the heavens.
What are the five?
First, when eating, some gods see other gods with white Suta colors, while their own food is dirty or sometimes red in color.
Eating together, seeing this, they feel extremely ashamed. This is the first shame.

The second shame is seeing other gods with excellent forms, wearing beautiful clothes and ornaments, with many heavenly maidens of exquisite beauty making offerings to other gods. Seeing this, they feel ashamed.
The third shame is seeing other gods in lotus flowers flying through the sky, walking in gardens, forests, mountain peaks, lotus ponds, and places of play made of gold and lapis lazuli.
Because of superior karma, their flying is swift.
If a god has little karma, their walking is not fast, and they cannot travel together with others, always lagging behind, ashamed of the heavenly maidens.
The fourth shame is that when the gods enter the lotus pond, due to the gods' original karma, there are lotus ponds born with color, fragrance, touch, and size.
When the inferior gods see this, they feel ashamed among their retinue.
The fifth shame is that as the gods' karma is, so is the retribution they receive, as they sit in their karmic seats.
If in the past they created great good karma, then there will be a wonderful vaidÅ«rya seat or a blue gem seat, or sometimes they will sit in an excellent seat with the color of a red lotus flower.

If other inferior gods sit in that place, due to their little karma, such a wonderful seat will either transform into gold, or transform into silver, or into crystal. When the gods see their seats transform like this, due to various mixed karmas - light, heavy, and so forth -
they will feel ashamed.
Because they feel ashamed, their majestic virtue diminishes.
The faces of those gods will lose their luster, while the faces of the other gods will become more radiant and majestic.
The celestial maidens will then abandon the gods of lesser karma and go to serve and attend to the gods of greater karma, enjoying themselves with them.
The celestial maidens will all go together to the other gods.
The gods of lesser karma will feel extremely embarrassed.
This is the fifth kind of embarrassment among the celestial retinue.
'In this way, one does not enjoy conditioned phenomena. Those conditioned phenomena are able to deceive and cause one to give rise to craving.

Just as tree leaves that have been processed are very bitter, but when mixed with other sweet flavors, the heavenly pleasures are also like this, mixed with suffering and mixed with joy. How much more so for those who are born in the realms of different paths, hell, hungry ghosts, and animals, either born from fixed karma or from unfixed karma, who constantly suffer without cease, and experience immeasurable kinds of powerful suffering.
It is like the various waters in the ocean, with different rivers entering and various waters entering.
The mind of sentient beings is also like this. The river of continuity flows, with various karmas. Relying on the river of karma, powerful sufferings arise and are accomplished.
You heavenly beings should know this extent. It is said that all kinds of different sufferings should be known.
In summary, all sufferings have three causes, which combine and correspond, and all sufferings are fulfilled.
These three kinds of suffering have three antidotes that can eliminate them.
What are the three?
They are wisdom, precepts, and giving.
At that time, Vipashyin Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
If the mind does not rely on wisdom, precepts, and giving,
Then sentient beings will always suffer, and happiness will be unattainable.
Like various causes and conditions, what kinds of karma are there?
In this way, the fruits are accomplished.ğŸ”½All are due to causes and conditions,
None are without causes and conditions,ğŸ”½The conditioned is not destroyed,
The causes and conditions are not seen.ğŸ”½Because the mind is deceived,
The face of generosity is ashamed,ğŸ”½Such a generous person,
Will not attain the blissful fruit.ğŸ”½Generosity that is harmonious is superior,
Abandoning the defilements of stinginess and jealousy,ğŸ”½Because the gods always experience bliss,
They do not have such thoughts.ğŸ”½Hunger and thirst are the great fire,
Which can burn all hungry ghosts,ğŸ”½The fruits of stinginess and jealousy,
Are truly spoken by the wise.ğŸ”½If one always practices generosity,
One will definitely attain bliss,
Because generosity attains blissful fruits, Therefore generosity is superior.ğŸ”½The light created in the world,
Always follows one,ğŸ”½Generosity leads to the heavens,
Where the gods make offerings like servants.
Generosity is not a deceptive place, the TathÄgata has said thus,
Because it is true, one should always practice giving.
Having abandoned stinginess and jealousy, and well cultivating the mind,
If one is able to practice generosity, one can cross the ocean of birth and death.
Giving to the Three Jewels' field of merit, the three kinds are all pure,
Definitely in the three times, the three eyes see that fruit.
First, always practice giving, next diligently guard morality,
Wisdom can then cut off love, this is the path to great joy.
If one does not eliminate love, the world will not benefit,
One will then be unable to reach the supreme place beyond birth and death.
Always avoid the mind of not giving, always delight in practicing giving,
Because of no giving, hungry and thirsty, the body is burned in the realm of hungry ghosts.
Through giving, one attains great wealth, among the gods and gandharvas,
Because of giving, one becomes a king, a virtuous and righteous wheel-turning king.
Relying on the ground of giving, the wise one is able to uphold the precepts.
One who upholds the precepts knows the right time, and through wisdom attains liberation.
The essential path to leaving suffering is praised by all Buddhas.
The courageous and valiant ones, knowing this, always practice giving.
Not giving leads to rebirth in the heavens, but the bliss experienced in the heavens is little.
Because of giving, one is reborn among humans, and from birth experiences abundant bliss.
If reborn among animals, one still always experiences blissful fruits.
All the bliss of giving is spoken of by the wise ones.
Even if reborn among hungry ghosts, they still have food and drink,
Because of having given a little in the past, one attains such fruits.
Even if reborn in the hells, hunger and thirst cannot burn them,
Because of giving, all attain such fruits.
Those born in the mud are the karma of these sentient beings.
Giving brings happiness, like seeing one's parents.
Thus abiding in the ground of giving, always practicing generosity,
Always delighting in giving and upholding precepts, one escapes all evil realms.

' The night spirit king Moxiu Loutuo thus showed the careless heavenly beings. The heavenly beings, having understood, all presently see the fruits of upholding precepts, and take up upholding precepts.
' ' Moreover, those heavenly beings are again ashamed, namely because of karma, they are ashamed in the present, ashamed to see food.

In the gardens, forests, and lotus ponds, they roam everywhere, surrounded by many heavenly maidens, with various delightful sounds, they walk in the heavens and on the ground, their minds delighting in the pleasures of the five desires, the supreme blissful pleasures are indescribable, they accomplish blissful matters.
In this way, the food and drink circulate and are passed around. Next, they go to the place of various beautifully adorned celestial maidens.
Surrounded by such celestial maidens, the gods sing, dance, and enjoy themselves to the sounds of the five types of musical instruments.
The auditory consciousness of those gods is never satisfied. The objects are so delightful that they can never be enjoyed enough.
Moreover, those gods see various colors that are all delightful, exquisite and wonderful, just as they wish. Seeing them, they experience joy.
Various lights, various different colors, and various shapes, whether far, near, or in between, when seen by those gods, they have such thoughts:
Those distant colors can come closer.
As they think in their minds, those delightful colors immediately come closer.
Or the colors in the middle come as they wish.
If they think of the near ones, the near ones come;
If they think of those in the middle, those in the middle will come;
if they think of those far away, those far away will come.
Because the results of karma are superior, they come as one wishes.
Because those karmic causes are of lower, middling, and higher levels, the heavenly rewards are also of lower, middling, and higher levels.
In this way, those gods, bitten by the poisonous snake of craving, are insatiable, like a fire that gets more fuel and never has enough.
Those with craving minds cannot be satisfied by objects, and in this way, the gods' immeasurable kinds of pleasures are all insatiable.
'Moreover, the gods' olfactory consciousness smells immeasurable kinds of fragrances, such as the heavenly, wondrous flower fragrances in the gardens and forests.

Furthermore, those flowers grow on the branches, with branches hanging down to the ground, having various colors, various shapes, various parts mixed together in various ways, all blooming at the same time.

The heavenly maidens pick these flowers and give them to the devas so that they can smell them, or the fragrance is carried to the devas by the wind. The devas smell them, and upon smelling them, desire arises and they experience sexual pleasure.
'Moreover, the bodies of the devas are adorned with such marvelous ornaments in accordance with the devas.
The ornaments on their heads, necklaces, and so forth, all appear according to the devas' thoughts.
Various garments have various fragrances, and the heavenly garments without threads are of appropriate size.
The devas, due to such arising of desire, are never satisfied.
'Moreover, if the devas think in their minds, due to their own karma, all that they need will be fully obtained, and there will be the most delightful food and drink.
In the heavens, there is food called sudhÄ on the ground.
Due to the original giving being of lower, middling, or upper levels, the sudhÄ is also like this, being of lower, middling, or upper levels.
Moreover, there are various heavenly drinks of lower, middling, or upper levels.
Because of such karma, one's own karma is like a seal.
Just as in the human realm, the length of a person's body corresponds to the position of the sun, and the shadow is also like this, long or short resembling the body.
In this way, in the past when those gods were among humans, they created such karma, and thus they are born to eat such food.
When they eat that food, heavenly maidens appear before them, and they then feel shame.
In this way, in the heavens they see superior heavenly maidens, and they experience great suffering.
In this way, within existence, all is impermanent, and there is no pleasure that is not destroyed. All conditioned things are seen to be like this. One should understand it thus.
Moreover, when the past good karma of those gods is exhausted and they are about to fall, they experience the suffering of decline.

If the careless gods who enjoy heavenly pleasures and desires are about to fall, when the love and separation, grease and moisture are exhausted, and they are about to go to another path, then signs appear.
Because of the desire to fall, the body and mind experience great suffering, and if great suffering arises,
that suffering is like this, indescribable.
The Buddha Vipashyin, at that time, spoke a verse, saying:
Various kinds of indulgent pleasures, deceived by objects,
When the desire for food is exhausted and about to retreat, there is no companion to accompany.
Before the heavens, indulging in pleasures, not practicing giving and so forth,
Later, when death and retreat arrive, remorse and heat burn the mind by oneself.
At the beginning, middle, and end, the mind always acts for benefit,
Benefiting those who are always disciplined, at the time of death, there is no fear.
There is birth, and there is necessarily death, and there is also the suffering of separation from what one loves,
The foolish one does not contemplate, deceived by objects.
Death, in sequence, moment by moment, objects destroy the heavens,
Coming to the heavens, unaware, because of being attached to desires with the mind.
If the heavens are able to know this, the suffering of separation from what one loves,
Even for a short while, the mind does not dwell on desires.
Desiring impermanence is to be feared, it always brings harm,
Yet the foolish still approach desire.
The deluded gods are always like this, burned by the fire of desire,
Having already been burned by desire, they continue to indulge without rest.
If one contemplates true reality, one will not delight in objects;
If one delights in desire, one will always weep.
This entire three realms turns and moves like a wheel,
Bound by the noose of all actions, the gods do not see the truth.
In the midst of various paths, they repeatedly die and are reborn,
Beings deluded by craving always experience suffering and distress.
Desire is like lightning or a fire wheel, it cannot be grasped for even a moment,
Like a dream or a gandharva, beings grasp at it in vain.
Desire is like this and so forth, fearing desire is even more so,
In impermanence, suffering, and emptiness, do not give rise to a sense of ownership.
This wheel of old age and death is extremely evil and difficult to subdue,
Like a being without rescue, without eyes, unaware.
The Sage has spoken of the five faculties, empty and without self-nature,
Often impermanent and suffering, their essence is a place of illness.
Having seen and known this, one should then abandon desire;
That tranquil wisdom is then close to abiding in nirvana.
For those heavenly beings about to fall, the faculties and mind all move and are disturbed,
At that time, suffering arises, which cannot be compared.
Thus experiencing great joy, thus with a mind of love and hatred,
When those heavenly beings are about to fall, they experience such great suffering.
For all who have not yet died, all who are free from the eight difficulties,
They should all bring about benefit, this path can bring about happiness.
Falling from the heavens to the ground, dying on the human ground,
Who, knowing this, would not be disgusted with birth and death?
Thus, when the heavenly karma is exhausted and one falls from the heavens, the rope of karma binds one, pulling one to fall, leading one to other places, causing great fear.
Therefore, there are heavens that are like animals.
If the heavenly mind delights in the enjoyment of objects, it is not for one's own benefit.
Therefore, the heavenly multitudes should not engage in heedless conduct, do not give rise to regret and remorse later.
The YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana thus, for the sake of the heavenly multitudes who roam in the place of the mountains and forests, the stÅ«pa made by VipaÅ›yin Buddha,
Having seen that stÅ«pa, taming the heavenly multitudes, bringing them benefit, showing the faults of desire.
For the upside-down heavens, the four upside-down ones, he expounds the true Dharma, before death arrives, he shows them death and gives them fear.
In that fearful place of death, in that place of immeasurable suffering, he shows the path of equality, with a tranquil mind benefiting others, taming the celestial beings.
In the six sutras, the text created by VipaÅ›yin Buddha is finished, the second one.

Moreover, that lord of the gods, the YÄma Heaven King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, together with the celestial beings who have come to the place of the mountains and trees, some with cultivated minds and some without, all accept them.
Diligent in cultivating the practice of benefiting others, removing their negligence, seeing the fruits of karma, causing their minds to be pliable;
because their minds are pliable, they give rise to great faith;
having given rise to faith, he shows their desires' faults;
having shown the faults of desires, he speaks of life's impermanence;
having spoken of impermanence, he speaks of the suffering of birth and death.
Having heard this, the gods' minds become pliable. Because their minds are pliable, the heavenly king says:

'You heavenly beings, all look at this great Buddha stupa, the stupa of the Tathagata Kakaguru, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One with Wisdom and Action Complete, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassed One, the Trainer of Those to Be Tamed, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One. The stupa of the Wonderful Jewel Buddha is filled with light, with golden beads and railings piercing through the sky, rising high above, all seeing it as extremely delightful, the foremost in purity. All the heavenly beings, seeing it, are delighted in their hearts.

Among these heavens, it rises high like a banner, firm and unmoving, just like abiding in meditation. The light of various good jewels is wonderfully supreme, just as the true Dharma says, the most delightful.
' The heavens see it like this.
'You heavenly beings, all follow me to that stupa to make offerings and pay homage, either by anointing it with incense or scattering flowers to make offerings.
What rare and wonderful things are there in this great sage's stupa?
Now let us go together to see.'
If it benefits me, up to nirvana, both body and life will be at peace and ease.
Why is it so?
The Tathagata, the World-Honored One, although speaking little of the Dharma, can still benefit and bring peace and joy to sentient beings.
All sentient beings will surely obtain benefits, without doubt.
We should now go together for our own benefit.'
At that time, when the heavenly multitudes heard the Heavenly King's words, their minds became pure, believing the Heavenly King's words, and said to the Heavenly King:
'We will all go to make offerings and pay homage, for our own benefit and peace and joy.'

At that time, the heavenly multitudes of the place of abiding in the mountains and forests, with the Heavenly King in front and the heavenly multitudes behind, went towards the World-Honored One's stupa, all going together.
Having arrived, they saw the stupa of the Tathagata Kakacupama, gave rise to a respectful and reverent mind, made offerings and paid homage, and circumambulated it.
At that time, the light of the various treasures in the stupa surpassed the light of the sun, like a firefly.
The light of those treasures was so excellent and wonderful.

In the Buddha's stupa, one sees hanging jeweled boards, with the foremost light. On the boards are the words of the sutra, which are the work of the spiritual powers of the devas. Therefore, they are not lost, not broken, not destroyed, and cannot be wiped away.
Why are they not lost?
Because the TathÄgata KÄÅ›yapa, for the benefit of the devas and humans, expounded this sÅ«tra, teaching the Dharma in this way to the devas and humans.
Why is this so?
Because among the heavens, this is the good path for humans, and among humans, this is the good path for the heavens.
When the heavens fall, they long for the good path of humans;
when humans die, they long for the good path of the heavens.
In this way, the heavens and humans take turns being the good path for each other. The heavens and humans take turns loving each other.
'If one upholds the precepts without breaking them, one will be reborn in the heavens.
There are two kinds of those who uphold the five precepts.
The one who observes precepts, due to ignorance, gives rise to but does not mature.

Only the ignorant do this. Although ignorant, they have faith. Because their minds have faith, they believe in the Buddha and others, and practice good conduct with body, speech, and mind, not wrong views.

Until the end of their lives, they believe in the results of karma, obtain things in accordance with the Dharma to sustain themselves, do not harm others, respect their parents, make offerings to their parents, associate with Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, and always listen to the true Dharma.
Such ignorant people only have faith and accord with it.
Although they are dull and ignorant, they fully practice good conduct with body, speech, and mind that accords with good karma. By their very nature, they do not accept precepts.
Such people, when their bodies perish and their lives end, are born in the good destinies, in the heavenly realms. Because their final thoughts were good, they are born in the heavens.
If reborn in the Heaven of YÄma, their bodies, colors, forms, garments, ornaments, celestial maidens, activities, and food will all be inferior, and they will feel ashamed.
Their radiance will also be less, and all their desires will be incomplete.
Because of their ignorance, they do not know how to take precepts. Compared to the celestial beings who have precepts and wisdom and know how to take precepts, they are inferior.

Moreover, because of their foolishness, they do not know how to take precepts and cultivate precepts. Although they give rise to pure faith in the Buddha and so forth, they are unable to take even one day of precepts, and their physical, verbal, and mental practices are incomplete.
As for physical good conduct, it means not killing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, and not stealing. This is not complete practice.
Only not lying, the other impurities of speech are all avoided.
Thus, only practicing a part of good conduct, one is unable to fully practice all good conduct.
If the mind is good, only believing in the end of life or having other karma, or sometimes only believing.

Being born in the Heaven of YÄma, the previous ones are even more inferior, compared to the other heavens who practice and uphold precepts, their size, body color, excellent ornaments, food, activities, celestial maidens, lifespan, sound, touch, color, and smell are all inferior.
Seeing their own inferiority, they are extremely ashamed and embarrassed before the other heavens who uphold precepts.
There are also fools who do not know how to take precepts and correspond with precepts.

Such people refrain from divisive speech for these two kinds of reasons.

It is solely because of their faith in the Buddha, or perhaps because of their superior merit, or perhaps because their inherent nature is superior, or because their minds are exceptionally gentle, or because their right views and deep faith are superior, or because they are not deceitful, not crooked, and do not cause others to be tormented in this way,

In this way, the superior karma, born above in the heavens, the result similar to the karma is definitely experienced, and is never false.
There is no doubt that it is not obtained. In this way, it is definitely obtained.
How much more so for taking the precepts, up to nirvana, which is definitely attained, and is never false.

Later, that person is burned by the fire of regret. Having been burned in this way, they abandon the training rules;
Having abandoned it in this way, one does not take it up again, and this is called a hole.
If a person does not abide in this way, it is called not having holes.

In this way, a moving mind joyfully takes up the precepts, with a mind of faith and respect. Later, having heard the teachings of non-Buddhists, the mind then gives rise to regret, and the mind becomes obscured by the defilements of delusion, and therefore one abandons the precepts.
Later, having heard the true Dharma, one again takes them up. This is called a gap.

With such doubts, he relied on the Dharma to uphold the precepts. This is called a hole.

Moreover, a hole means that there is a hole in the inner mind, but externally one acts well, for the sake of being seen by others, for the sake of offerings, and upholds the precepts. This is called a hole.
